name: Tokutei-meisho-shu (special designation sake)
summary: Tokutei-meisho-shu is premium sake that must meet specific criteria; the system includes eight categories based on polishing rate, alcohol addition, and brewing methods.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

specs.classification.tokutei_meishoshu.evidence_quote: Premium](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22evidence_quote%22:%22Premium) sake that is required to pass certain criteria.

original_text_snippets: Premium sake that is required to pass certain criteria.

name: Junmai (junmai-shu)
summary: Junmai-shu is sake made without the addition of neutral spirits, and is treated as a special designation category.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

specs.classification.junmai.evidence_quote: Sake](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22evidence_quote%22:%22Sake) made without the addition of neutral spirits.

original_text_snippets: Sake made without the addition of neutral spirits.

name: Honjozo (honjozo-shu)
summary: Honjozo-shu is a special designation sake made with rice polished to 70% or less and a limited addition of neutral spirits.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

specs.classification.honjozo.evidence_quote: Sake](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22evidence_quote%22:%22Sake) made with rice polished down to 70% or less

original_text_snippets: Sake made with rice polished down to 70% or less.

name: Ginjo (ginjo-shu)
summary: Ginjo-shu is a special designation sake made with rice polished to 60% or less and fermented at low temperature; it is often described as fruity and light.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

specs.classification.ginjo.evidence_quote: Sake](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22evidence_quote%22:%22Sake) made with rice polished down to 60% or less

original_text_snippets: It is characterized by a fruity aroma and light flavor.

name: Daiginjo (daiginjo-shu)
summary: Daiginjo-shu is a special designation sake made with rice polished to 50% or less and fermented at low temperature; it is often described as fruity and light.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

specs.classification.daiginjo.evidence_quote: Sake](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22evidence_quote%22:%22Sake) made with rice polished down to 50% or less

original_text_snippets: Sake made with rice polished down to 50% or less.

name: Futsu-shu
summary: Futsu-shu is sake that is not categorized as a special designation (tokutei-meisho-shu), either by choice or for not meeting the criteria.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

specs.classification.futsushu.evidence_quote: Sake](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22evidence_quote%22:%22Sake) that is not categorized as a specially designated sake

original_text_snippets: Sake that is not categorized as a specially designated sake.

name: Ginjo aroma (ginjo-ka)
summary: Ginjo-ka is the fruity aroma associated with ginjo and daiginjo sake, attributed to factors like polishing, yeast choice, and low-temperature fermentation.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: A fruity aroma is characteristic of ginjo and daiginjo sakes.

name: Ginjo method (ginjo-zukuri)
summary: Ginjo-zukuri refers to the method used to make ginjo/daiginjo-type sake, commonly involving heavy polishing, tsukihaze-style koji, and low-temperature fermentation.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: A special method for making ginjo/daiginjo.

name: Genshu
summary: Genshu is sake that is not diluted with water for alcohol adjustment; it is typically higher in alcohol (often over 17%).

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

specs.production.dilution.genshu.evidence_quote: not](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22evidence_quote%22:%22not) diluted with water for alcohol content adjustment

original_text_snippets: Sake that is not diluted with water for alcohol content adjustment.

name: Happo-seishu (sparkling sake)
summary: Happo-seishu is sake with effervescence; the fizziness may come from fermentation, post-addition, or secondary fermentation.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: Sake that has effervescence.

name: Namazake
summary: Namazake is unpasteurized sake; it is often described as fresh and vibrant and is typically kept refrigerated due to active enzymes.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: Unpasteurized sake.

name: Namachozo (namachozo-shu)
summary: Namachozo-shu is sake pasteurized only once at bottling.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: Sake pasteurized only once at bottling.

name: Namazume (namazume-shu)
summary: Namazume-shu is sake pasteurized only once after filtration.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: Sake pasteurized only once after filtration.

name: Hiire (pasteurization)
summary: Hiire is heat pasteurization used to sterilize sake and inactivate enzymes; it is commonly performed after filtration and at bottling.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: Sake is heated to around 60-65℃ to sterilize.

name: Hiyaoroshi
summary: Hiyaoroshi is winter-brewed sake aged over summer and bottled in autumn; it is pasteurized only once after filtration.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

specs.production.pasteurization.hiire.evidence_quote: Pasteurization](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22evidence_quote%22:%22Pasteurization) is done only once after filtration.

original_text_snippets: aged over summer, and bottled in autumn.

name: Shiboritate (fresh sake)
summary: Shiboritate refers to freshly pressed sake.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: Freshly pressed sake.

name: Shinshu (new brew)
summary: Shinshu refers to new sake of the current brewing season.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: New sake of the current brewing season.

name: Nigori (nigori-zake)
summary: Nigori-zake is cloudy sake filtered with a coarse mesh; it is often described as milky and creamy.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

specs.production.texture.nigori.evidence_quote: Cloudy](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22evidence_quote%22:%22Cloudy) sake that is filtered with a coarse mesh.

original_text_snippets: Cloudy sake that is filtered with a coarse mesh.

name: Taruzake (casked sake)
summary: Taruzake is casked sake with a slight cedar aroma that comes from storing sake in cedar casks.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: Sake that has a slight aroma of cedar wood.

name: Kijoshu
summary: Kijoshu is a sweet sake style where sake is added to the mash in addition to water.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

sweetness.sweetness_level.evidence_quote: Kijoshu](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22evidence_quote%22:%22Kijoshu) is a special type of sweet sake.

original_text_snippets: In addition to water, sake is added to the mash.

name: Kan-zukuri (cold-season brewing)
summary: Kan-zukuri refers to sake making carried out exclusively in the cold season, a method used to help prevent microbial contamination.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: Sake making exclusively in the cold season.

name: Kan-agari
summary: Kan-agari is a term used when a sake’s flavor is enhanced by warming.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: A term used when a sake’s flavor is enhanced by warming.

name: Koshu (jukusei-shu) — aged sake
summary: Koshu (also referred to as jukusei-shu) is sake professionally aged for more than two years after brewing; it may develop amber color and caramelly aroma.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: professionally aged for more than two years after brewing.

name: Seimai-buai (rice polishing rate)
summary: Seimai-buai is the rice polishing rate, expressed as the percentage of the grain remaining after polishing.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: Rice polishing rate is the percentage of what is left after polishing.

name: Sakabayashi (sugidama)
summary: Sakabayashi, also called sugidama, is a cedar decoration hung at the entrance of a sake brewery and is traditionally a sign of new sake.

sources.title: Glossary](https://japansake.or.jp/sake/en/basic/glossary/%22,%22title%22:%22Glossary) of Sake Terms
sources.publisher: Japan Sake and Shochu Makers Association (JSS)

original_text_snippets: A decoration made of cedar leaves hung at the entrance of a sake brewery.
